member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.AnalysisResult.Steps
member.summary: Indicates all solving steps that the solver has recorded.
member.remarks: The result value is not when the property is not .

summary.para: Indicates the maximum difficulty of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the maximum value among all difficulty ratings in solving steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, or else the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 20M.
Indicates the total difficulty rating of the puzzle.

When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps recorded in . However, if the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first solving step. If the puzzle has not solved or the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 0.
Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .

When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first step before the first one whose conclusion is . If the puzzle has not solved or solved by other solvers, this value will be 20.0M.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.AnalysisResult.Deconstruct(System.Boolean@,System.Int32@,System.Collections.Generic.IReadOnlyList{Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo}@)

remarks.para: The method should be declared manually when the type is a normal or . If the method is in a (or a ), the deconstruct method will be generated by the compiler automatically and returns all properties to those parameters.

Please note: If the deconstruct method is automatically generated by the compiler, you can't create a deconstruct method manually with the same number of the parameters than that auto method; otherwise, the method can't be called normally.
In addition, the deconstruct methods can take more than 8 parameters, although a normal can only contain at most 8 parameters.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.FastProperties
member.summary: Provides and encapsulates the fast properties that is used in solving and analyzing a sudoku puzzle.

remarks.para: The whole class is a one, which means you can't use clause to create a new instance of this type. In contrast, the class is used for providing with properties used in a cyclic manual searching (i.e. in ).
Some step searchers rely on this class. If you want to call them alone, you should ensure the method in this class is called before using these properties.

If a step searcher doesn't rely on this class, it'll be marked an attribute named . If you find that the step searcher marks that attribute, you can call it everywhere safely; however, if the searcher isn't marked that attribute, you can't call it everywhere unless you call the method .

Please note, all names of properties in this class can also be found in , which means you can also call the property by . Of course, some of them doesn't contain the same one in , but you can find a same property whose execution logic (handling logic) is totally same. For example, is same as . The difference between them is that you shouldn't use until you have called , while can be used everywhere, because it isn't an instant property (which means the calculation begins when you called them, i.e. lazy ones; in contrast, some properties only store values directly, so their values can be got instantly, i.e. instant ones).

summary.para: Indicates whether the solver should check ALS cycles.
The value is in default case.
Indicates whether two ALSes can be overlapped with each other.
The value is in default case.
Indicates whether all ALSes shows highlight regions instead of cells.
The value is in default case.
Indicates whether the solver should check all technique information using the strict technique searchers order.

If the value is , all technique searchers will be enabled calculation in order. It ensures the strictness of difficulty rating that the maximum difficulty searched in one searcher should be no more than the minimum one searched in the searcher behind the previous one.

The value is in default case. In addition, if this value is , the option will be disabled. In other words, this option doesn't work while solving when the condition is satisfied. However, the time of calculation with this value will be much slower than that with the value is .
Indicates whether the solver should check the technique Almost Locked Quadruple (ALQ).
The value is in debug environment, and in release environment.

Indicates whether the solver will check the validity of the conclusions after searched them. If the conclusions eliminate the wrong digits or assign to the wrong cells, it will report the error (i.e. throw a ).

The value is in default case. If the value is , all conclusions will be checked before applying to the grid. The comparer is the solution grid. Computer doesn't know which conclusions are correct and which ones are incorrect. Therefore, the best plan is to compare to the solution grid. If not, the solver won't check the validity of all conclusions. In other words, the solver doesn't stop the searching until the grid is totally invalid (None of eliminations or assignments can be searched). However, unfortunately, the grid has no solution at present.
Indicates whether the solver should check Gurth's symmetrical placement at the initial grid.

The value is in default case. In addition, if the value is , the solver will check the symmetry of the grid at initial. If the grid is symmetrical grid, the solver will give you a hint about the technique of symmetrical placement. However, the hint will influence the difficulty rating during solving the puzzle. If the puzzle is so easy (in other words, the grid doesn't need check it), this option will make the difficulty rating of the puzzle much more higher than that when the option is . In addition, if the option is , this option will be ignored.
Indicates whether the solver should check incomplete uniqueness patterns.
The value is in debug environment, and in release environment.
Indicates whether the solver should search for extended unique rectangles.
The value is in debug environment, and in release environment.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.ManualSolver.EnableFullHouse

summary.para: Indicates whether the solver will record the step whose name or kind is full house.
The value is in default case.

member.remarks: Full houses are the techniques that used in a single region. When the specified region has only one empty cell, the full house will be found at this empty cell (the last value in this region).

summary.para: Indicates whether the solver enables the garbage collection after finished searching a technique whose searcher is high space-complexity.
This value is in default case.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.ManualSolver.EnableLastDigit

summary.para: Indicates whether the solver will record the step whose name or kind is last digit.
The value is in default case.

member.remarks: Last digits are the techniques that used in a single digit. When the whole grid has 8 same digits, the last one will be always found and set in the last position, which is last digit.

summary.para: Indicates whether the solver will apply multiple technique usages at the same time if searched more than one technique. As for the option is , when searched more than one technique instance which holds a same difficulty, the searcher will apply them at the same time; however if the value is , the solver will apply all same techniques searched at the same time.
The value is in default case. If the value is , the solver will enable this mode to accelerate the running, but the applied techniques will be added much more than when the value is .
Indicates whether the step accumulator only records template delete, and template set won't be in this collection (if necessary).
If the value is , and the solver has checked all template steps, only template deletes in these steps will be recorded into the step accumulator.
The value is in default case.
Indicates whether the searcher will only display same-level techniques in Find All Steps tab page.
The value is in default case.
Indicates whether the solver will optimizes the applying order.
When the value is , the result to apply to the grid will be the one which has the minimum difficulty rating; otherwise, the applying step will be the first one of all steps being searched.
The value is in default case. If the value is , the option will be disabled.
Indicates whether the solver should order all technique searchers by its priority.

The value is in default case. In addition, if you enable the option , this option will be disabled because the solver will enable the function of count on all steps and get one with the minimum difficulty of them.
Indicates whether the solver should use extended BUG checker to searcher for all true candidates no matter how difficult the true candidates looking for.
The value is in debug environment, and in release environment.
Indicates whether the solver should check advanced eliminations during finding exocets.
The value is in default case.
Indicates whether the solver will show cross hatching information single techniques).
The value is in debugger mode, and in release mode in default case.
Indicates the number of nodes to be searched for in bowman bingoes.

The value is 32 in default case. You can let this value be higher because this value take a little influence on the solver. However, each unique solution has more than 17 hints (given digits), which means you can't set this value more than 64 (81 - 17 = 64).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.ManualSolver.CheckRegularWingSize

summary.para: Indicates all regular wings with the size less than or equals to this specified value. This value should be between 3 and 5.
The value is 5 in default case.

member.remarks: In fact this value can be 9 at most (i.e. value is >= 3 and <= 9) theoretically.

summary.para: Indicates the max petals of death blossom to search.
The value is 5 in default case.
Indicates the max size of the complex fish to search.
The default value is 5.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Alses.Als.Deconstruct(System.Int32@,System.Int16@,Sudoku.Data.Cells@)

remarks.para: The method should be declared manually when the type is a normal or . If the method is in a (or a ), the deconstruct method will be generated by the compiler automatically and returns all properties to those parameters.

Please note: If the deconstruct method is automatically generated by the compiler, you can't create a deconstruct method manually with the same number of the parameters than that auto method; otherwise, the method can't be called normally.
In addition, the deconstruct methods can take more than 8 parameters, although a normal can only contain at most 8 parameters.

member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is M-Wing ((x = y) - y = (y - x) = x).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Chaining.AicStepInfo.IsSplitWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is Split-Wing (x = x - (x = y) - y = y).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Chaining.AicStepInfo.IsHybridWing
member.summary:
Indicates whether the chain is Hybrid-Wing. This wing has two types:
(x = y) - y = (y - z) = z
(x = y) - (y = z) - z = z

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Chaining.AicStepInfo.IsLocalWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is Local-Wing (x = (x - z) = (z - y) = y).

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Chaining.AicStepSearcher
member.summary: Encapsulates an (grouped) alternating inference chain ((grouped) AIC) or (grouped) continuous nice loop ((grouped) CNL) technique searcher.
member.remarks: I want to use BFS (breadth-first searching) to search for chains, which can avoid the redundant backtracking.

The other candidate mask. If failed to check, the value will be -1.

summary.para:
Indicates an exocet pattern. The pattern will be like:
.-------.-------.-------. | B B E | E . . | E . . | | . . E | Q . . | R . . | | . . E | Q . . | R . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | | . . S | S . . | S . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
BBase Cells.
Q1st Object Pair (Target cells pair 1).
R2nd Object Pair (Target cells pair 2).
SCross-line Cells.
EEscape Cells.

In the data structure, all letters will be used as the same one in this exemplar. In addition, if senior exocet, one of two target cells will lie in cross-line cells, and the lines of two target cells lying on can't contain any base digits.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Singles.SingleStepSearcher.ShowDirectLines
member.summary: Indicates whether the solver shows the direct lines (cross-hatching information).

remarks.para:
Direct lines is a concept that describes the crosshatching information of a hidden single. For example, in this following grid:
.---------.---------.---------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . 1 | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :---------+---------+---------: | . . 1 | x x x | . . . | | . . . | x . x | . . . | | . . . | x x x | 1 . . | :---------+---------+---------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | 1 . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '---------'---------'---------'
The start point of the direct lines are:
r4c3(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r4c456
r2c6(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r456c6
r6c7(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r6c456
r8c4(1), removes the cases of digit 1 for cells r456c4
All the end points may be displayed using a cross mark ('x'), and the start point may be used a circle mark ('o').

param.name: ConjugateRegion
param.para: The so-called conjugate region.
A conjugate region is a serial of cells that all lies in a same region, but only these cells can be filled with the digits specified, other cells in this region can't be filled with that digit.
Although the name of this term is conjugate "region", but a region can contain not only those cells at present.

member.param: Indicates the mask of digits that is the combination.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Uniqueness.Polygons.Pattern
member.summary: Indicates the borescoper's deadly pattern.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.Uniqueness.Polygons.Pattern._mask
member.summary: Indicates the internal structure.

remarks.para:
This mask is of type :
0 7 14 21 28 35 42 49 56
|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|
where the bit [0..56] is for 8 cells, the last 7 bits determine the pattern is a heptagon or a octagon. If the value is 127 (not available), the pattern will be a heptagon.
Due to the rendering engine, you have to check this file rather than the tip window.

remarks.para: The method should be declared manually when the type is a normal or . If the method is in a (or a ), the deconstruct method will be generated by the compiler automatically and returns all properties to those parameters.

Please note: If the deconstruct method is automatically generated by the compiler, you can't create a deconstruct method manually with the same number of the parameters than that auto method; otherwise, the method can't be called normally.
In addition, the deconstruct methods can take more than 8 parameters, although a normal can only contain at most 8 parameters.

members.member:
Indicates the options aiming to s while searching, which is the newer implementation of the type .
Indicates the priority of this technique.
Indicates which areas the step searcher is enabled and works well. The default value is both and .
Indicates the displaying level of this technique.
The display level means the which level the technique is at. All higher leveled techniques won't display on the screen when the searchers at the current level have found technique instances.
In order to enhance the performance, this attribute is used on . For example, if Alternating Inference Chain (AIC) is at the level but Forcing Chains (FC) is at the level , when we find any AIC technique instances, FC won't be checked at the same time
This attribute is also used for grouping those the searchers, especially in Sudoku Explainer mode.
Indicates whether the current searcher has bug to fix, or something else to describe why the searcher is (or should be) disabled.
Indicates how stable the technique behaves.
In the future, if the technique is unstable, we may modify the order slightly via algorithm to find some special techniques, such as exocets.
.

member.summary: To clean the grid.
member.remarks: "To clean a grid" means we process this grid to fill with singles that is found in , and remove eliminations that is found in and . The process won't stop until the puzzle cannot use these techniques.

Full houses and last digits may not be found in this method due to the limitation of the algorithm.

member.summary: Encapsulates all information after searched a solving step, which include the conclusion, the difficulty and so on.

summary.para: Indicates whether the difficulty rating of this technique should be shown in the output screen. Some techniques such as Gurth's symmetrical placement doesn't need to show the difficulty (because the difficulty of this technique is unstable).
If the value is , the analysis result won't show the difficulty of this instance.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.Name
member.summary: Indicates the technique name.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.Acronym
member.summary: Indicates the acronym of the step name. For example, the acronym of the technique "Almost Locked Candidates" is ALC.
member.remarks: This property only contains the result in English. Other languages doesn't contain any abbreviations by default. On the other hand, this is really an easier way to implement than storing values in resource dictionary files.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.Format
member.summary: Gets the format of the current instance.
member.returns: Returns a result. If the resource dictionary doesn't contain any valid formats here, the result value will be .

remarks.para:
A format is the better way to format the result text of this technique information instance, It'll be represented by the normal characters and the placeholders, e.g.
"{Name}: Cells {CellsStr} => {ElimsStr}"
Here the string result shouldn't be with the leading '$' character, because this is a format string, rather than a interpolated string.

Because this property will get the value from the resource dictionary, the property supports multiple language switching, which is better than the normal methods and . Therefore, this property is the substitution plan of those two methods.

member.summary: The difficulty level of this step.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.IsAlmostLockedSets
member.summary: Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is an Almost Locked Sets (ALS in abbreviation).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.IsChaining
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a chain. The chain techiques are:
Wings
Regular wings (XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing, WXYZ-Wing, etc.)
Irregular wings (W-Wing, M-Wing, Split-Wing, Local-Wing, Hybrid-Wing)
Short chains
Two strong links (Skyscraper, Two-string kite, Turbot fish)
ALS chaining-like techniques (ALS-XZ, ALS-XY-Wing, ALS-W-Wing)
Empty rectangle
Long chains
Forcing chains
Dynamic forcing chains

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.IsDeadlyPattern
member.summary:
Indicates whether the corresponding technique of the current step is a deadly pattern. The deadly pattern techniques are:
Bi-value patterns
Unique rectangle (i.e. Uniqueness test)
Unique loop
Bi-value universal grave
Multi-value patterns
Extended rectangle
Unique square
Borescoper's deadly pattern
Qiu's deadly pattern
Other deadly patterns
Reverse bi-value universal grave

member.remarks: Most of techniques uses eliminations so this property is named ElimStr. In other words, if the conclusion is an assignment one, the property will still use this name rather than AssignmentStr.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.StepInfo.Deconstruct(System.String@,System.Decimal@,Sudoku.Solving.Manual.DifficultyLevel@)

remarks.para: The method should be declared manually when the type is a normal or . If the method is in a (or a ), the deconstruct method will be generated by the compiler automatically and returns all properties to those parameters.

Please note: If the deconstruct method is automatically generated by the compiler, you can't create a deconstruct method manually with the same number of the parameters than that auto method; otherwise, the method can't be called normally.
In addition, the deconstruct methods can take more than 8 parameters, although a normal can only contain at most 8 parameters.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.TechniqueProperties.OnlyEnableInAnalysis
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher is only used in analyzing a sudoku grid. If , when in find-all-step mode, this searcher will be disabled.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Solving.Manual.TechniqueProperties.DisplayLevel
member.summary: Indicates the display level of this technique.

remarks.para: The display level means the which level the technique is at. All higher leveled techniques won't display on the screen when the searchers at the current level have found technique instances.

This attribute is used on . For example, if Alternating Inference Chain (AIC) is at level 1 and Forcing Chains (FC) is at level 2, when we find any AIC technique instances, FC won't be checked at the same time in order to enhance the performance.
This attribute is also used for grouping those the searchers, especially in Sudoku Explainer mode.
Note that the property is different with .
